Award.AwardTitle: US-China Workshop on Biosensing and Bioactuation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a joint research workshop on Bio-inspired Sensing and Actuation Technologies (BISAT) to be held in Shanghai, China, November 8-12, 2010. Its objectives include promotion of research collaboration between researchers in the two countries and particularly engagement of researchers from both the life sciences and engineering to stimulate cross-disciplinary as well as transnational collaborations. The program, which will involve about 40 participants including some advanced students and young researchers, will focus on the formulation of a vision for new approaches to BISAT and its opportunities. The meeting is intended to promote linkages between the research communities in the two countries. The Chinese participation will be supported by the National Science Foundation of China.
The workshop will engage leading researchers from two domains of science from the two countries to produce a vision and a roadmap for future interdisciplinary research efforts in BISAT. Both countries have identified this area as a high priority for development because of the wide range of possible applications. It is expected that the resulting cross-fertilization will be quite productive.
In addition to addressing numerous research issues in the field, the workshop will discuss practical applications of new bio-inspired sensing and actuation technologies to critical areas of societal concern such as infrastructure health and medical systems. Also, participation of students in the workshop will have an educational impact. The meeting will bring together participants from both countries to establish long-term collaborative relationships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) recently initiated programs are growing into global interest in research at the cross-disciplinary pioneering frontier of biosensing and bioactuation (BSBA).  In 2010, the NSF made 12 BSBA team four year research awards, primarily to engineering and bio researchers, each with a budget of US $2.0 Million under its Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI) program. This initiative has opened the door widely to enable visionary researchers in the biosciences and engineering to integrate their talents across the boundaries of their traditional disciplinary divides, and it has generated significant international interest including follow up programs by European Science Foundation (ESF) and Japan Science and Technology Agency (JST) and others to encourage proposals for international collaboration on BSBA research.  Development of a program in this area with great potential was recently initiated by NSF and the National Science Foundation of China (NSFC). To drive forward and ensure success of this pioneering program in development of a large dynamic, multidisciplinary research community across the Pacific and in support of challenging collaborative research projects between the US and China, this award supported a three-day workshop in Shanghai, China, with the objective of stimulating international collaborations and leading to transformative, cross-disciplinary research on Advanced Sensors and Bio-Inspired Technologies (ASBIT). One of the two key goals of the workshop was to provide the foundation needed for establishing bilateral US-China research collaborations on development of advanced sensors and the use of bio-inspired technologies. The second goal was to expand and identify appropriate bio and life sciences subject-areas for joint US-China research challenges to better reflect the strength and interest of the bio science research domains of both countries. 

Outcomes that demonstrate that these goals were achieved include the unprecedented and strong response of over 40 full research proposals submitted to the NSF within a year after this workshop for the collaboration of US and Chinese researchers in the field of biosensing and bioactuation. All of these proposals were submitted to both the NSF and NSFC, and requested the NSF support the US PI's efforts, and the NSFC support the Chinese PIs team members research efforts. They included plans for on-going collaborations and many included plans for student exchange between the two countries. Additionally, funds that supported this award were used to train and provide 7 US graduate students and post-doctoral students with the opporutnity to travel to China. While attending the workshop, they met with students and researchers and learned about the broad international community in which they will conduct research as they pursue their professional research careers.
